data.key: Each business SHOULD maintain an inventory of critical data assets categorized per the Data Handling Policy.
Inventory of critical assets SHOULD be updated upon deletion or addition.
Data SHOULD be encrypted in transit and at rest per the Data Handling Policy. This will ensure data is protected when compromised.
To minimize the blast radius of a compromised service, all services SHOULD block all communication except for that that is needed for the service to function as intended.
Multi-Factor Authentication MUST be implemented as prescribed by the Data Handling Policy under "Authentication" for all interactive end-user access to data.
"Least Privileges Principle" SHOULD be used when assigning privileges to a user or service.

Escalating levels of privilege SHOULD be protected through additional levels of authorization. Some examples of these levels of authorization are separate accounts, re- entry of authentication credentials (su root), and explicit assumption of an IAM role.
Administrators of the following enterprise services MUST NOT use their everyday user account for logins or configuration changes.

To facilitate collaboration with the different lines of business, all services SHOULD integrate with an Identity Provider (IdP) that supports the latest protocols for identity federation and authentication.
To mitigate theft, all credentials MUST be encrypted when stored or transmitted.
The use of ssh keys protected by a passphrase is an acceptable practice.
Enterprise user credentials MUST be rotated every 180 days when MFA is enabled, every 90 days if MFA is not enabled.
Shared credentials SHOULD be changed within 24 hours after the departure of any individual with access to those credentials.
Shared credentials MUST be changed within 7 days after the departure of individuals with access to those credentials.
If MFA is not technically feasible, a password of at least 21 characters SHOULD be used.
API Keys/Security Tokens SHOULD be rotated within 90 Days and MUST be rotated within 180 days.
Actions executed by an administrative user MUST be logged.
All administrative action log data MUST be retained for 30 days in a raw unaltered state.
Network traffic SHOULD be monitored for malicious activity.
Authentication successes and failures
Authorization (access control) failures
System start-ups and shut-downs
Addition, deletion, or modification of groups
Changes to privileges
All system log data SHOULD be retained for 30 days in a raw unaltered state.
Log data older than 30 days SHOULD be archived for at least 1 year.
All enterprise systems (pc, laptop, tablet, phone) MUST require a password or biometric login.
Idle remote desktop user sessions SHOULD auto-lock after 15 minutes.
Idle ssh connections SHOULD disconnect after 15 minutes.
Idle remote desktop user sessions SHOULD auto-lock after 15 minutes.
All enterprise systems MUST install an Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) agent for COMPLIANT Crowdstrike is used as EDR detecting and responding to malicious behavior.
To mitigate the exploit of patched vulnerabilities, all systems SHOULD be patched with the latest patches on a monthly cycle.
Systems that are End of Life AND cannot receive security patches MUST NOT be used.
